summary:
A1 French Unit Summary

Vocabulaire Clé (Key Vocabulary)

  • Salutations et Phrases Communes: Bonjour (Hello), Non (No), Oui (Yes), Ah (Ah).
  • Noms (Nouns): un chat (a cat), un chien (a dog), un croissant (a croissant), une pizza (a pizza), une orange (an orange), un garçon (a boy), une fille (a girl), un homme (a man), une femme (a woman).
  • Verbes (Verbs): mange (eats/is eating), ai (have), as (have).

Grammaire Essentielle (Essential Grammar)

1. Les Pronoms Sujets et le Verbe Être (Subject Pronouns and the Verb To Be)

  • The verb "to be" (être) is introduced with the first three persons: je suis (I am), tu es (you are, singular informal), il est (he is/it is, masculine), elle est (she is/it is, feminine).
  • Use Je suis Marie (I'm Marie) to introduce yourself.
  • Use Tu es Marc? (Are you Marc?) to ask someone's name/identity.

Remember that tu es is informal and used with friends, family, or people your age. French distinguishes between the formal "you" (vous) and informal "you" (tu).

2. Le Genre des Noms (Gender of Nouns)

  • All French nouns are either masculine or feminine.
  • Masculine nouns use the article un (a/an): e.g., un chat, un chien, un homme, un garçon.
  • Feminine nouns use the article une (a/an): e.g., une pizza, une femme, une fille.
  • C'est un chat means "It's a cat."

Do not guess the gender of a noun based on its meaning! Learn the noun with its article (un or une) from the start. For example, une orange is feminine, even though its meaning is gender-neutral in English.

3. Le Verbe Avoir (The Verb To Have)

  • The verb "to have" (avoir) is used to talk about possessions.
  • Present tense forms used: tu as (you have), j'ai (I have). Note the contraction j'ai used before a vowel sound (instead of je ai).
  • Use Tu as un chien? (Do you have a dog?) to ask about pets.

When asking questions like "Do you have..." (Tu as...), beginners often forget the standard word order. Simply raising your voice at the end of the statement (intonation) is the easiest way to form a question in A1 French.

Key Vocabulary Summary (A1 Greetings & Farewells)

  • Greetings and Politeness:
    • Bonjour (Hello)
    • Merci beaucoup (Thank you very much)
    • Bien / très bien / ça va bien (Fine / very well / it's going well)
    • Ça va (It's okay/fine)
    • Et toi? (And you? - informal)
  • Farewells:
    • Au revoir (Goodbye)
    • Bonne journée (Have a nice day)
    • À bientôt (See you soon)
    • À demain (See you tomorrow)
  • Food Vocabulary:
    • un croissant (a croissant)
    • une pizza (a pizza)

Grammar Focus: Simple Questions and Responses

  • Asking How Someone Is:
    • The phrase Comment ça va? (How are you doing?) is a very common way to greet someone.
    • The response often uses Ça va... followed by a state (e.g., Ça va bien, Ça va très bien).
    • To return the question in an informal setting, use Et toi? (And you?).

    • Pro-tip: Do not confuse Comment ça va? (How are you?) with Comment tu t'appelles? (What is your name?). Always remember to include the verb va or allez when asking about well-being.

  • Basic Verbs and Negation:
    • The phrases show basic usage of verbs like mange (eat) and suis/est (implied state of being, e.g., Ça va).
    • Negation in French typically involves ne...pas (e.g., Non, je ne mange pas une pizza. - The provided example simplifies this to just "Non" or uses an affirmative verb like "mange"). The example Non, je mange une pizza shows a simple negative response followed by an affirmative statement.

    • Pro-tip: While the content uses simple "Non" to refuse, remember that proper French negation uses two parts: ne before the verb and pas after it (e.g., je ne mange pas). Practice using the full negation early on.

A1 Unit Summary: Introductions, Languages, and Preferences

Key Vocabulary

  • Greetings/Politeness: Bonjour (Hello), Excuse-moi (Excuse me), Merci (Thank you).
  • Self/Identity: Je m'appelle (My name is), Mon ami s'appelle (My friend's name is), Qui est (Who is), Mon passeport (My passport).
  • Nationalities: français/française (French), américain/américaine (American), espagnol/espagnole (Spanish), Mexicain (Mexican), anglaise (English).
  • Food/Preferences: les croissants (croissants), les éclair (éclairs), les gâteaux (cakes), les fruits (fruits).
  • Verbs/Expressions: Tu parles français? (Do you speak French?), Je ne suis pas disponible pour l'instant (I am not available at the moment), Tu préfères (Do you prefer).

Grammar Points

Verb: Être (To Be)
  • Conjugations seen: Je suis (I am), Tu es (You are, informal), Il est (He is), Elle est (She is).
  • This verb is essential for stating identity and nationality (e.g., Je suis française).

Beginners often forget to use être when stating nationality. Remember to say Je suis américain, not just Je américain.

Verb: Parler (To Speak) - Regular -ER Verb
  • Conjugations seen: Je parle (I speak), Tu parles (You speak), Il parle (He speaks), Elle parle (She speaks).
  • The conjugation pattern for parler is typical for most regular French verbs ending in -er.

The pronunciations for Je parle, Tu parles, Il parle, and Elle parle sound identical, even though the spelling changes. Focus on clear pronunciation and using the correct subject pronoun (Je, Tu, Il, Elle).

Verb: Préférer (To Prefer) - Regular -ER Verb Variation
  • Conjugations seen: Je préfère (I prefer), Tu préfères (Do you prefer/You prefer).
  • Used to express likes and preferences (e.g., Je préfère les gâteaux).

Notice the accent change in the infinitive (préférer) compared to the conjugated forms (préfère, préfères). The change from 'é' to 'è' helps indicate pronunciation changes.

Gender Agreement (Feminine vs. Masculine)
  • Nationalities change form depending on the subject's gender: Il est américain (Masculine) vs. Elle est américaine (Feminine).
  • The feminine form often adds an 'e' to the masculine form (e.g., espagnol vs. espagnole).

Always check the gender of the person you are describing. If the subject is female, you must use the feminine form of the adjective: Sarah est espagnole.

A1 Unit Summary: Introductions, Location, and Work/Study

Vocabulary

  • Greetings and Farewells:
    • Bonjour! (Hello!)
    • Salut. (Hi/Hello.)
    • Au revoir! (Goodbye.)
    • Bonne journée! (Have a nice day!)
    • Pardon. (Sorry/Excuse me.)
    • Enchantée. (Nice to meet you. - feminine)
    • Bienvenue! (Welcome!)
  • Personal Information:
    • Comment tu t'appelles? (What's your name?)
    • Je m'appelle... (My name is...)
    • Et toi? (And you? - informal)
    • Comment ça va? (How are you?)
    • Ça va bien. (I'm doing well.)
    • Oui. (Yes.)
    • Non. (No.)
  • Professions and Status:
    • journaliste (journalist)
    • professeur/professeure (teacher/professor)
    • étudiant/étudiante (student)
    • professeur de sport (sports teacher)
    • professeur d'art (art teacher)
  • Places and Objects:
    • ici (here)
    • livre (book/pound)
    • ordinateur (computer)
    • tableau (painting, board, chart)
    • université (university)

Grammar Rules

  • The Verb ÊTRE (To Be):
    • Used to state identity, profession, and status.
    • Conjugation examples seen: Je suis (I am), Tu es (You are).
    • Example: Je suis étudiant. (I am a student.)

    Avoid translating word-for-word from English. In French, you do not need an article (like 'a') when stating a profession after être, unless you add an adjective. Say Je suis journaliste, not Je suis un journaliste.

  • The Verb HABITER (To Live):
    • Used to indicate residence.
    • Conjugation examples seen: J'habite (I live), Tu habites (You live), Marie habite (Marie lives).
    • Prepositions for location: Use à for cities (J'habite à Paris.) and en for most countries that are feminine or start with a vowel (J'habite en France., J'habite en Angleterre.).

    Remember the difference between à (for cities) and en (for many countries). Also, habite is often contracted to J'habite because it starts with a vowel.

  • The Verb TRAVAILLER (To Work):
    • Used to indicate employment.
    • Conjugation examples seen: Je travaille (I work), Tu travailles (You work).
    • Example: Je travaille à Paris. (I work in Paris.)

    The pronunciation of the first person singular (Je travaille) and the second person singular (Tu travailles) is identical. Context is key!

  • The Verb ÉTUDIER (To Study):
    • Used to indicate the act of studying.
    • Conjugation examples seen: J'étudie (I study), Tu étudies (You study).
    • Often followed by the subject (e.g., l'anglais, l'espagnol) or a location (à New York, en France).

    Like habiter, étudie is often contracted to J'étudie. Be sure to include the preposition à when studying in a city (J'étudie à Paris).

Vocabulary Summary

Places and Destinations

  • la gare: the train station
  • l'aéroport: the airport
  • un restaurant (français/mexicain): a restaurant (French/Mexican)
  • Paris, Lyon, Marseille, Espagne: cities and country

Transportation and Travel

  • le train: the train
  • l'avion: the plane
  • la voiture: the car
  • un taxi: a taxi
  • le billet d'avion: the plane ticket
  • une valise: a suitcase
  • un passeport: a passport

Key Phrases

  • Où est... s'il vous plaît?: Where is... please?
  • À bientôt!: See you soon!
  • Bonne journée.: Have a nice day.
  • Bon voyage!: Have a good trip!
  • près de la gare: near the station

Grammar Rules

1. The verb Aller (To go)

  • je vais (I go/I'm going)
  • tu vas (you go/you're going - informal)
  • il va, elle va (he/she goes)
  • on va (we go/we will)

Remember that aller is highly irregular. Use Je vais à (I am going to) when talking about a destination (e.g., Je vais à Paris).

2. The verb Avoir (To have)

  • j'ai (I have)
  • tu as (you have - informal)
  • il a, elle a (he/she has)

Be careful with the spelling of tu as. It is not tu ai. Use j'ai before a vowel (e.g., J'ai un passeport).

3. Definite Articles

  • le: used for masculine singular nouns (e.g., le garçon)
  • la: used for feminine singular nouns (e.g., la femme)
  • l': used for singular nouns starting with a vowel or silent 'h' (e.g., l'homme, l'aéroport)

In French, almost all nouns have a gender (masculine or feminine). Always learn the noun with its article (e.g., un passeport, une valise) to remember its gender.

Vocabulary Summary

  • Family Members (Ma Famille)
    • mon père (my father)
    • ma mère (my mother)
    • ton frère (your brother)
    • ta sœur (your sister)
    • son fils (his son)
    • sa fille (her daughter)
    • mon grand-père (my grandfather)
    • ma grand-mère (my grandmother)
    • mon cousin (my cousin)
    • la famille (the family)
    • le mari (the husband)
  • Pets (Les Animaux de Compagnie)
    • un animal de compagnie (a pet)
    • un chat (a cat)
    • un chien (a dog)
  • Places & Locations
    • ici (here)
    • en France / en Espagne / en Italie / à Paris (in France / in Spain / in Italy / in Paris)
    • le restaurant (the restaurant)
    • l'hôtel (the hotel)
    • le jardin (the garden)
  • Useful Words & Phrases
    • chouette (nice, cool)
    • utile (useful)
    • d'accord (okay, all right)
    • veux venir (want to come / want to go)

Grammar Focus

1. Possessive Adjectives (Mon, Ma, Ton, Ta, Son, Sa)

  • Possessive adjectives agree in gender and number with the noun they modify, not with the owner.
  • Use mon, ton, son before masculine singular nouns (e.g., mon père, ton frère).
  • Use ma, ta, sa before feminine singular nouns (e.g., ma mère, ta sœur).
  • The structure 's possession is translated using de (e.g., le chat de Marie - Marie's cat).

Pro-tip: Remember to match the adjective to the object's gender! Even if the speaker is female, she says mon père (masculine object) and ma mère (feminine object).

2. Verb Conjugations (Habiter - To Live, S'appeler - To Be Called)

  • The verb habiter (to live) is a regular -ER verb: J'habite, Tu habites, Il/Elle/On habite, etc.
  • The verb s'appeler (to be called) is used to ask names: Comment s'appelle ton frère? (What is your brother's name?).
  • Key question words include Où (Where) and Comment (How/What).

Pro-tip: For -ER verbs like habiter, the forms for je, tu, il/elle/on sound almost identical, but they have different spellings (e.g., il habite vs. tu habites). Focus on the tu form when asking questions to friends/family (Où habites-tu?).

3. Expressing Existence (Avoir - To Have)

  • The verb avoir (to have) is used to talk about pets: J'ai un chat. (I have a cat).
  • It is also used to express possession of family members: J'ai un frère et une sœur. (I have a brother and a sister).

Pro-tip: Avoir is irregular! Memorize its key forms like j'ai (I have) and tu as (you have). Do not confuse it with the verb 'to be' (être).

Vocabulaire Clé

Noms de Lieux Communs

  • le parc (the park)
  • le cinéma (the cinema)
  • l'école (the school)
  • le restaurant (the restaurant)
  • le zoo (the zoo)
  • la boulangerie (the bakery)
  • Paris / Montréal (cities)
  • lavabo (washbasin)
  • lit (bed)

Nourriture et Boissons

  • un croissant (a croissant)
  • le chocolat (chocolate)
  • une pizza (a pizza)
  • une orange (an orange)
  • de la laitue (lettuce)

Moyens de Transport

  • en bus (by bus)
  • en métro (by subway)

Expressions Utiles

  • Je suis fatigué(e) (I am tired)
  • C'est une bonne journée (It's a good day)
  • mon animal de compagnie (my pet)

Règles de Grammaire A1

1. Le Verbe «Aller» (To Go)

  • Conjugaison au présent pour les pronoms utilisés:
    • Je vais (I go)
    • Tu vas (You go - informal)
    • Il/Elle va (He/She goes)
    • Nous allons (We go)
    • Ils/Elles vont (They go)
  • Utilisé pour indiquer un mouvement vers un lieu: Je vais au parc.

Faites attention aux contractions des prépositions devant les lieux: on dit au (à + le) pour les noms masculins singuliers (au travail, au restaurant), et à l' pour les noms qui commencent par une voyelle ou h muet (à l'école).

2. Les Articles Définis et Partitifs

  • le, la, l', les (the) pour parler de choses spécifiques: J'aime la musique.
  • du, de la, de l', des (some/any) pour parler d'une quantité non spécifiée (souvent pour la nourriture): Je veux du chocolat.

Rappelez-vous que du est la contraction de de + le. Utilisez du pour les noms masculins (du chocolat) et de la pour les noms féminins (de la laitue).

3. Verbes d'Opinion et d'Action (1er Groupe - en -ER)

  • Verbes rencontrés: aimer (to like/love), manger (to eat), étudier (to study), lire (to read - 3ème groupe, mais important ici), habiter (to live).
  • Leur conjugaison est régulière pour aimer, manger, étudier, habiter (e, es, e, ons, ez, ent). Exemple avec aimer: J'aime, Nous aimons.

Le pronom Nous est toujours suivi de la terminaison -ons (Nous mangeons, Nous habitons). C'est une marque de conjugaison très fiable.

Key Vocabulary

  • People/Family: famille (family), amie (friend, female), meilleure amie (best friend, female), les gens (people), frère (brother), professeur (teacher), chauffeur de taxi (taxi driver), fille (girl).
  • Places/Locations: ici (here), là-bas (over there), en France (in France), à Paris (in Paris), au Luxembourg (in Luxembourg), aux États-Unis (in the United States), à la gare (at the station), l'université (university), l'hôpital (hospital), appartement (apartment), maison (house), magasin (store), boulangerie (bakery), église (church), parc (park), en ville (in the city).
  • Adjectives/Descriptions: intéressant (interesting), cher/chère (expensive), super (great), difficille (difficult), content/contente (happy/satisfied), bien (well/good), désolé (sorry).
  • Nouns/Objects: voyage (trip), veste (jacket), couleur (color), anniversaire (birthday), euro (euro), taxi (taxi), travail (job/work), journal intime (diary), chocolat (chocolate), valise (suitcase), train (train), arbres (trees), fleurs (flowers).
  • Time/Frequency: maintenant (now), souvent (often), parfois (sometimes), aujourd'hui (today), bientôt (soon), bonne nuit (good night).
  • Verbs: aimer (to like/love), aller (to go), étudier (to study), travailler (to work), habiter (to live), parler (to speak), prendre (to take), vouloir (to want), conduire (to drive), ouvrir (to open), connaître (to know).

Grammar Focus

Asking Questions (Interrogation)

  • Beginner French uses several ways to ask questions:
  • Rising Intonation (Informal): A simple declarative sentence becomes a question by raising your voice at the end (e.g., Tu parles chinois. -> Tu parles chinois?).
  • The phrase Est-ce que... (Formal/Neutral): Not seen here, but useful for yes/no questions.
  • Inversion (More Formal): Inverting the subject pronoun and verb, separated by a hyphen (e.g., Habites-tu...?, Travailles-tu...?).
  • Question Words (Q-words): Use words like Qui (Who), Où (Where), Quand (When), Pourquoi (Why) at the beginning of the sentence (e.g., Où habites-tu?).

Beginners often forget the hyphen when using inversion (e.g., Parles-tu). Also, remember that question words like Où and Pourquoi must be followed by a verb structure.

Common Regular -ER Verbs

  • The content frequently uses regular verbs ending in -er, such as travailler (to work), habiter (to live), aimer (to like/love), and étudier (to study).
  • In the present tense, these follow a consistent pattern: Remove -er and add endings (je: -e, tu: -es, il/elle/on: -e, nous: -ons, vous: -ez, ils/elles: -ent).
  • Example: J'habite (I live), Tu habites (You live), Nous aimons (We like).

Pay close attention to pronunciation: the singular forms (je, tu, il/elle) and the third person plural (ils/elles) often sound identical, even though the spellings are different (e.g., J'étudie and Ils étudient sound the same).

Prepositions of Location

  • Prepositions are essential for discussing where you live or where you are going.
  • À: Used for cities (e.g., à Paris, à la gare).
  • En/Au/Aux: Used for countries/regions: en is used for feminine countries (en France), au for masculine countries (e.g., au Luxembourg), and aux for plural countries (aux États-Unis).
  • Près de/d': Means 'near' (e.g., près d'un parc, près de la gare). The 'de' contracts to d' before a vowel sound (e.g., l'église).

A common mistake is confusing 'in' for a city (à) versus 'in' for a country (en/au/aux). Always use à before city names.

Vocabulary Review

Time and Scheduling

  • midi (noon)
  • minuit (midnight)
  • matin (morning)
  • soir (evening, pm)
  • tard (late)
  • tôt (early)
  • heure (hour/o'clock)
  • minute (minute)

Food and Drinks

  • café (coffee)
  • lait (milk)
  • sucre (sugar)
  • thé (tea)
  • chocolat (chocolate)
  • glace (ice, ice cream)
  • milk-shake (milkshake)
  • petit-déjeuner (breakfast)
  • faim (hunger/hungry)

Places and Objects

  • cuisine (kitchen)
  • frigo (fridge)
  • horloge (clock)
  • placard (cupboard)
  • musée (museum)
  • sculpture (sculpture)
  • sac à dos (backpack)

Verbs and Actions

  • venir (to come)
  • devoir (must, to have to)
  • manger (to eat)
  • prendre (to take, to have [a drink/meal])
  • boire (to drink)
  • sortir (to go out, to leave)
  • rentrer (to go/come home)
  • partir (to leave)
  • se lever (to get up)
  • jouer (to play)
  • comprendre (to understand)
  • connaître (to know)

Grammar Focus

Telling Time (L'heure)

  • Use Il est... to state the time. Example: Il est huit heures du soir. (It is 8 pm.)
  • For noon and midnight, use midi and minuit. Example: Tu dors a midi? (Do you sleep at noon?)
  • Fractions of an hour: et quart (a quarter past), et demie (half past), moins le quart (a quarter to).

Remember that du matin is used for AM and du soir for PM, except for midi and minuit.

The Present Tense (Le Présent) and Modal Verbs

  • The verb devoir (must/have to) is frequently used, often followed by an infinitive verb. Example: Je dois venir. (I must come.)
  • Common present tense conjugations observed: Je viens (I come), Nous venons (We come), Je sors (I go out/leave).

Be careful with word order when using devoir: the main verb stays in the infinitive (unconjugated) form directly after dois.

Making Offers and Requests

  • To offer something, use Tu veux un peu de...? (Do you want a little bit of...?)
  • To accept, respond with Oui, je veux un peu de... (Yes, I want a little bit of...)
  • For a polite request, use Je voudrais... s'il te plaît. (I would like... please [informal]).

Use un peu de (a little) or just du/de la/des (some) when discussing food and drink, indicating a partitive relationship. Don't forget s'il te plaît for informal requests.

Vocabulary Summary

  • Formal Address/Titles:
    • Monsieur: Mister, Mr., gentleman, sir
    • Mademoiselle: Miss
    • Madame: Mrs., Madam, Lady
  • Key Phrases & Greetings:
    • Excusez-moi: Excuse me
    • Bonne journée: Have a nice day
    • De rien: You're welcome
    • À bientôt: See you soon
    • Pas de problème: No problem
    • Je ne sais pas: I don't know
  • Nouns (Travel & Places):
    • la compangnie aérienne: the airline company
    • le vol: flight
    • bagages/valise: luggage/suitcase
    • arrivée: arrival
    • le prénom: first name
    • le nom de famille: the last name
    • la nationalité: nationality
    • l'Afrique: Africa
    • une question: a question
    • carte: card, map, menu
    • portefeuille: wallet
    • clés: keys
  • Nouns (Food & Drink):
    • quelque chose: something
    • jus d'orange: orange juice
    • café: coffee
    • thé: tea
    • légumes: vegetables
    • dessert: dessert
    • pizza: pizza
  • Verbs & Actions:
    • trouver: to find
    • attendre: to wait for, to await, to expect
    • venir: to come (e.g., Vous venez d'Italie? - Are you from Italy?)
    • voyager: to travel
    • manger: to eat
    • boire: to drink
  • Adjectives & Colors:
    • violet/voilette: purple
    • bleu(e): blue
    • jaune: yellow
    • rouge: red
    • en retard: late (e.g., Le vol est en retard)
    • seule: alone (feminine)
    • intéressant: interesting
    • important: important
    • raison: reason (often used in Vous avez raison - You are right)

Grammar Focus

1. Formal vs. Informal Address (Tu vs. Vous)

  • The content focuses heavily on the formal 'You' (Vous) for respectful interactions (e.g., Voulez-vous manger ici?, Comment allez vous, Monsieur Dumas).
  • The informal 'You' (Tu) is used between friends (e.g., Tu aimes le vin?, Tu es en retard).

Beginners often mix up Tu and Vous. When in doubt with a stranger, service provider, or superior, ALWAYS use Vous. Only use Tu with friends, family, children, or people who invite you to do so.

2. Asking Questions (Interrogative Adjectives)

  • Quel/Quelle (Which/What) changes gender to match the noun it precedes:
    • Masculine singular (Quel): Quel train va à Paris? (Which train...)
    • Feminine singular (Quelle): Quelle est votre destination? (What is your destination?)
  • Common interrogative forms include inversion (less frequent here) or using Est-ce que (implied by context) or simply raising your voice/adding a question mark (e.g., Vous venez d'Italie?).

Remember that Quel must agree with the noun's gender. If you are asking for a feminine noun (like destination or profession), use Quelle.

3. Expressing Wants and Preferences (Vouloir and Conditional)

  • The verb Vouloir (to want) is used in two main forms in the context:
    • Present Tense (Direct): Je veux une pizza (I want a pizza). This is strong.
    • Conditional (Polite Request): Je voudrais (I would like) is much more polite (e.g., Je voudrais du jus, s'il vous plaît).

To sound polite in French, especially when ordering food or drink, always use the conditional form Je voudrais instead of the simple present Je veux (I want). Using Je veux can sound demanding.

4. Possession (Mon, Ma, Mes, Votre)

  • The possessive adjectives change based on the gender and number of the object possessed:
    • Ma valise (My feminine suitcase)
    • Mes bagages (My plural luggage)
    • Votre nom de famille (Your formal/plural last name)

Possessive adjectives like ma, mon, and mes must agree with the object being possessed (the noun), not the person who possesses it. For example, Ma valise (My suitcase) is used even if the speaker is male, because valise is feminine.
